docs.snippet: LEAD: THE Housatonic Museum of Art's collection numbers more than 500 works. They run from African sculptures to Pop Art, from a Mughal painting to a figurative sculpture by Lee Bontecou, from Giorgio de Chirico to Alfonso Ossorio and from lesser...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE Housatonic Museum of Art's collection numbers more than 500 works. They run from African sculptures to Pop Art, from a Mughal painting to a figurative sculpture by Lee Bontecou, from Giorgio de Chirico to Alfonso Ossorio and from lesser Dutch masters to Leonard Baskin. It's quite a gamut.

headline.main: Prints and Drawings By Latin Americans

docs.snippet: LEAD: The streets and piazzas were quiet today. But city officials here were bracing for trouble. All the elements that could lead to the worst incidents of hooliganism since the World Cup soccer finals began early last month were moving into place.

headline.main: World Cup '90;   Haunted by a Tragedy, Turin Braces for England-West Germany

byline.original: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

headline.main: Each Country's Agenda at the Economic Summit Meeting

docs.snippet: LEAD: President Bush plans to tell the United States' six main industrial allies this week that he is prepared to send teams of experts to the Soviet Union to help it rebuild rail and communications networks, grain storage sites, food distribution...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: President Bush plans to tell the United States' six main industrial allies this week that he is prepared to send teams of experts to the Soviet Union to help it rebuild rail and communications networks, grain storage sites, food distribution systems and other essential services, senior White House officials said today.

headline.main: U.S. PLANS TO SEND PEOPLE, NOT CASH, TO ASSIST SOVIETS

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations may arrive at decisions in Houston this week that can make or break the present Uruguay Round of multinational trade talks. If they listen to food exporting countries, especially in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations may arrive at decisions in Houston this week that can make or break the present Uruguay Round of multinational trade talks. If they listen to food exporting countries, especially in the third world, they will hear this: Open up markets, or forget about new trade rules on services and intellectual property.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The leaders of the seven richest Western nations began their 16th annual summit conference in the tropical heat of Houston this afternoon, with an intractable dispute over trade policy threatening to disrupt the unity of the three-day meeting.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The leaders of the seven richest Western nations began their 16th annual summit conference in the tropical heat of Houston this afternoon, with an intractable dispute over trade policy threatening to disrupt the unity of the three-day meeting.

headline.main: U.S. PUSHES TO END FARMING SUBSIDIES

byline.original: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Houston summit meeting resolved no important dispute. The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations did more agreeing to disagree than agreeing. But to judge their annual economic conference a failure is hasty. The leaders differed...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Houston summit meeting resolved no important dispute. The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations did more agreeing to disagree than agreeing. But to judge their annual economic conference a failure is hasty. The leaders differed about how to aid the Soviet Union. Dismayingly, they condoned help for China.

headline.main: Summit Promise - and Shame;   A Chance, at Least, for Fair Farm Policy

docs.snippet: LEAD: Beyond the debates on Bavarian cowherds and Japanese rice farmers, beyond the conventions on global forests and jousts on the Uruguay Round, a more subtle, personal roundelay was taking place this week.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Beyond the debates on Bavarian cowherds and Japanese rice farmers, beyond the conventions on global forests and jousts on the Uruguay Round, a more subtle, personal roundelay was taking place this week.

headline.main: The Personal Means a Lot These Days

headline.main: Excerpts From Economic Declaration by Chiefs of Seven Industrial Nations

docs.snippet: LEAD: Negotiators began discussing a compromise plan today to cut subsidies in world farm trade, a proposal that leaders of the world's richest industrial democracies backed at their economic summit meeting in Houston this week.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Negotiators began discussing a compromise plan today to cut subsidies in world farm trade, a proposal that leaders of the world's richest industrial democracies backed at their economic summit meeting in Houston this week.
